HABANA,
April 27, 1937.
Gen. Albert E. Truby,
U. S. Army, Retired,
145 Laurel Street,
San Francisco, Cal.
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
Thru the courtesy of General Kean I received some three weeks ago
a copy of the photograph of the Hospital Corps Detachment, Columbia Barracks,
Quemados, Cuba, taken in September, 1900. In a recent letter from General
Kean he informed me that I was one of the group, offering to send me the
photograph as soon as he felt certain of my correct address.

I regret to inform you that No. 15, indicated as your humble servant,
is not John J. Moran. That was a disappointment to me since I have no photo-
graphs of my own taken prior to December, 1917. I am inclined to believe
that No. 15 is either Folk or Weatherwalks. No. 14 is not Kneisley, I am
morally certain, and just as morally certain am I that it is Warren G. (not J)
Jernegan. I am sure that if you were to consult Mrs. Jernegan by sending
her a copy of the photograph, she would bear me out.

There is still another reason, altho not a conclusive one, why I
could not appear in the group. I was discharged from the Army on July 2, 1900,
and at the time the photograph was taken I was Order Clerk in Major Robert E.
Lee Michie's office, Headquarters of Western Cuba, Marianao, General Fitzhugh
Lee's headquarters, Major Michie being Adjutant General. In passing, I
might state that General Kean, at that time Major Kean, Chief Surgeon on Gen.
Lee's staff, was instrumental in having me appointed Order Clerk. Also, in
a group of this nature, my place would have been in a line with the non-comm-
issioned officers seated in the row back of yourself, Doctors. Pinto, Amador
and Cooke, having been appointed A. H. S. on recommendation of the late Col.
George D. Deshon, at that time commandant of the Hospital School of Instruct-
ion, Washington Barracks, D. C., under whom I took the six months' course.
I believe I was appointed within a month after we declared war on Spain.
Captain Deshon considered me an exemplary student, hence his recommendation
to the Surgeon General that I be promoted.

No, he

Since the copy of photograph came to me under somewhat of a mis-
apprehension, so to speak, I am entirely willing to surrender it altho I would
like to hold on to it as a memento of many of the faces shown thereon and
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
Gen. Albert E. Truby.
-- 2 --
April 27, 1937.
whose friendship, comradeship and/or acquaintance is now a pleasant memory,
including your goodself in one of said categories.

I wish to apologize for my failure to write to you immediately I
received copy of the photograph, but think I have an alibi. I have been laid
up for the better part of three weeks due to an infection having its inception
in a small blister which appeared on the sole of my heel and which I punctured
with what I thought was a sterile needle. The infection extended to my ankle
joint, the swelling around the joint area, accompanied by discoloration and
extreme tenderness having given me no little concern. For letter writing
I am lost without my typewriter although I am credited with writing plainly
and neatly. When I was at Guanajay Barracks, under Captain Quinton, the
Sick & Wounded Reports prepared and written by me elicited favorable comment
in General Kean's office, at General Lee's headquarters, for their neatness
and completeness. None the less, I write few letters in long hand, very
frequently violating that phase of the social code.

If you should care to drop me a line in connection with the contents
of this letter I shall be most pleased to hear from you. Much water has gone
over the dam since February, 1901, when I bid goodbye to all of you at Columbia
Barracks. You may recall that Kissinger and myself sailed on the Morro Castle
with Doctor Reed, the latter headed for Washington and the former enjoying a
furlough in God's Country. I came North to kill time until the opening of
the session at the University of Virginia in September.

Please overlook the length and rambling nature of this letter and
accept kindest personal regards of your former subordinate and friend,

John J. Moran, I replied to this but did
